image.altText: plane on tarmac with man walking down

props.synopsis: Hundreds of employees of embattled budget airline Bonza are told their employment has been officially terminated at an online meeting.

title.children: Bonza staff sacked at a 'virtual meeting' two months after the budget carrier went bust

image.altText: A man in a shirt, tie and jacket stands with the Sydney Harbour Bridge in the background.

props.synopsis: Nicholas Sampson engaged high-profile barristers Arthur Moses SC and Sue Chrysanthou SC, and solicitor Rebekah Giles to represent him, before reaching the confidential settlement.

title.children: Ex-Cranbrook headmaster settles with school as he lodges 'detailed complaint' over ABC program

image.altText: A courtroom sketch of Greg Lynn

props.synopsis: Prosecuting lawyers are making their final arguments in the murder trial of former Jetstar pilot Greg Lynn, who is charged with the murder of Carol Clay and Russell Hill.

title.children: Jurors urged to reject accused murderer Greg Lynn’s account of camper deaths as 'elaborate fiction'

image.altText: Model pic sent to scam victims

props.synopsis: In the Dubai desert lies a scam factory capable of swindling tens of thousands of people at a time. But one scammer has a secret plan that could shut the whole syndicate down.

title.children: Inside a secret scam factory where workers pretend to be glamorous models

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaks to someone off camera during a television interview.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton says the Coalition will wait until it has returned to power and looked at "the prevailing economic conditions" before it sets a 2030 climate target.

title.children: Dutton says Coalition will not set 2030 climate target before next election

image.altText: People watch on at the Territory Day fireworks celebrations at Mindil Beach in 2021.

props.synopsis: The fireworks party, one of the biggest events on the NT calendar, will be moved from Mindil Beach because the NT Major Events Company has not obtained an authority certificate from the NT's sacred sites watchdog.

title.children: For the first time in 20 years, the NT's Territory Day fireworks won't be held at its most iconic beach

image.altText: A graphic of a nuclear power plant with a nuclear symbol and the numbers 2040 and 2045 in the foreground

props.synopsis: As the shift away from fossil fuels gathers pace, the Coalition has turned to an emissions-free technology with a long and contentious history — nuclear fission. These are the numbers you should keep in mind when thinking about its place in Australia's energy transition.

title.children: Would a nuclear power plant fit Australia's needs? These numbers cut through the debate

image.altText: CCTV of two young men looking around a home

props.synopsis: More than 40,000 Queenslanders want Castle Law to use lethal force against home intruders, but the law society says existing laws allowing reasonable force have served the community well.

title.children: Laws allowing people to kill home intruders would be 'state sanctioned murder', law society warns

image.altText: Jibril Rajoub  wearing a blue blazer and white button-down shirt

props.synopsis: Jibril Rajoub was denied a visa ahead of a FIFA World Cup qualification match in Perth tonight, a month after pushing for Israel to be removed from FIFA over its actions in Palestine.

title.children: Palestinian football boss says Australia denied visa 'under the pressure' of Israel ahead of FIFA qualifier

image.altText: Michael Mosley speaks on a morning talk show wearing a blazer, blue shirt and glasses

props.synopsis: British TV presenter Michael Mosley died of natural causes, with a post-mortem examination finding no evidence of foul play.

title.children: Television doctor Michael Mosley died of natural causes, reports say

image.altText: A photo showing people holding disposable cups and plates.

props.synopsis: Despite having the greatest need for funding in Australia, with a homelessness rate 12 times the national average, the NT has persistently not received enough Commonwealth money because of its small population. But in May, that changed.

title.children: 'Game changing' federal funding is chance to finally start fixing homelessness in the NT, advocates say

image.altText: Chickens bathed in red light at night in a shed

props.synopsis: While supermarket shelves were stripped bare of egg cartons, the storage room at Wes Humpage's farm was reaching capacity. Until today.

title.children: Egg farmers near avian influenza outbreak scramble into action after week-long lockdown lifted

image.altText: A close-up shot of a shopping trolley full of groceries in a supermarket with a woman behind bagging apples.

props.synopsis: Queensland's treasurer has handed down a big-spending pre-election budget, offering up $3.7 billion in new cost-of-living relief – unapologetically plunging the state into deficit.

title.children: Election-year Queensland budget throws $3.7b at cost-of-living relief thanks to coal windfall

image.altText: An illustration of a map of Australia highlighting Queensland.

props.synopsis: Population growth and cost-of-living relief are the headline drivers of spending and revenue in Queensland's 2024 election year budget.

title.children: These are the winners and losers in this year's Queensland budget

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

props.synopsis: A 44-year-old Canberra man is charged with a range of offences after a woman was found running screaming and naked along a street on Monday evening, police say.

title.children: Man charged after woman allegedly found running naked and screaming along Canberra street

image.altText: A grey short-hair cat sits on an open laptop on a home office desk.

props.synopsis: Australians are being warned this tax time not to double dip on working-from-home claims, make sure they have detailed records of expenses and not to lodge their tax returns too early.

title.children: Tax time is fast approaching and the ATO has a warning to those with work-from-home claims

image.altText: An Israeli military convoy

props.synopsis: The UN Security Council has backed plans for an Israel-Gaza ceasefire and Hamas has welcomed the resolution, saying it will cooperate with mediators.

title.children: 'Time to halt the killing': UN Security Council backs US plan for Gaza ceasefire

image.altText: Man wearing red top and large S chain smiles at camera.

props.synopsis: Two boys aged 12 have been convicted of the murder of a 19-year-old man who was fatally stabbed in England last year.

title.children: Boys, 12, found guilty of murdering man in machete attack

image.altText: Christian Petracca

props.synopsis: The Demons confirm star midfielder Christian Petracca underwent overnight surgery after suffering a lacerated spleen in the King's Birthday match, with a timeline yet to be determined on his return to play.

title.children: Demons reveal Petracca suffered lacerated spleen, punctured lung, broken ribs in brutal clash

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt being escorted by a detective in plain clothes.

props.synopsis: Details about the days leading up to the death of Diana Hanbury are revealed during a bail application for her father Adam Hanbury.

title.children: Parents charged with murder over death of 'gravely unwell' toddler believed she may have been teething, court told

image.altText: A 1970s TV still of an older, balding man with a moustache and wiry eyebrows

props.synopsis: Robert Baudin printed around $2 million in fake US notes. When he (eventually) faced court, he took to the air and threatened to crash into Sydney Harbour.

title.children: This man told his wife he was printing pornography. What he was doing was much more sinister

image.altText: A crushed can of mixer floats in the dirty incoming tide

props.synopsis: The Director of Liquor Licensing announces the sale of takeaway alcohol in the Kimberley town of Derby will be banned each Sunday and Monday, alongside further restrictions on trading hours in Broome.

title.children: Further booze bans to be introduced in WA's Kimberley, with limits on trading hours

image.altText: A drone shot of housing development and green pastures, divided by a single road.

props.synopsis: Developers are building half-width streets in Western Sydney due to current planning laws, as local councils and the state government blame each other over the issues the narrow roads are creating for residents.

title.children: NSW government and councils blame one another over 'absurd' half-width streets

image.altText: A black tunnel emerges from a white airliner on an airport tarmac, with people in yellow hi-vis vests standing at the entrance.

props.synopsis: Singapore Airlines has offered compensation to passengers who were on board a flight that encountered severe turbulence and led to dozens of injuries and one death last month.

title.children: Singapore Airlines offers $15,150 in compensation to passengers on flight hit by severe turbulence

image.altText: Steph Catley holds a ball

props.synopsis: Matildas coach Tony Gustavsson is determined to leave Paris with a medal draped around his neck, but says his team "stands for so much more than just the result".

title.children: 'It's so much more': Matildas won't let Olympics define golden generation's legacy

image.altText: Drone shot of Lincoln prison

props.synopsis: Police have confirmed a 23-year-old man died in Port Lincoln Prison on June 4.

title.children: Police confirm death of 23-year-old Indigenous man in South Australian prison

image.altText: A man cuddling a dog

props.synopsis: The faithful pooch Blue travels about 6.4 kilometres to a campsite where his owner man had been staying with family, alerting them something is wrong.

title.children: Dog raises alarm after owner crashes car into ravine

image.altText: Football coach Graham Arnold on the touchline, screaming instructions to his players

props.synopsis: Australia are already guaranteed passage through to the next phase of qualifying after winning their opening five games.

title.children: Arnold says Socceroos will have nine changes for World Cup qualifer

image.altText: Tim Cook stands in front of a screen with an Apple logo.

props.synopsis: Apple is finally making its big AI move, and it matters more than most flashy big tech launches for two reasons.

title.children: Ding dong, Apple has finally arrived at the AI party. So what did it bring?

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is falling sharply despite overnight gains for Wall Street and a $1.8 billion takeover offer for Autobarn. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX slides sharply, private equity lobs $1.8b offer for Autobarn

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Foreign Investment Review Board has no objections to foreign acquisition of CSR
Businesses conditions and confidence both fall in May: Westpac survey
'The RBA may not have hiked enough'

image.altText: A woman in a blue pattern shirt

props.synopsis: Raewyn Pepper is one of about 200,000 Australians affected by schizophrenia. She says despite talk of the state government making improvements to mental health services she thinks it is "a bit of a fallacy".

title.children: Raewyn has lived with mental illness for 30 years. She says accessing treatment has worsened over time

image.altText: Two young white kids holding hands, running through long grass

props.synopsis: Studies suggest the absence of "risky play" in the modern world could be contributing to the teen mental health crisis. Here's what it's all about.

title.children: 'Just like I used to do': Why Peter wants to give his children an 80s childhood
